utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So what kind of cruise is this you’re going on?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: It’s called the Born Again Boat Ride. Christian Quarterly gave it their highest rating, five thorny crowns. I do wish you’d come with me, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, Mom, if I did, it would be conclusive proof that your God can work miracles.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You’re missing out. It’s gonna be wall-to-wall fun. It’s all themed. There’s Jonah and the Whale Watching, all-you-can-eat Last Supper Buffet, and my personal favourite, Gunning with God.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s Gunning with God? I’m afraid to ask.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, it is a hoot and a half. You write your sins on a clay pigeon, they fire ’em up in the air, and you pulverize them with a 12-gauge shotgun full of our Lord’s forgiveness.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Frankly, Mom, I’m encouraged to see how advanced your group has become, willing to sail out into the ocean without fear of falling off the edge.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: For example, if Shelly was aboard, he’d write “smart mouth” on his pigeon, and then bam!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The Lord giveth and the Lord bloweth away. Well, Mom, according to my itinerary for our weekend together, the fun begins with fried chicken.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Sounds delicious.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good, ’cause I got you everything you need to make it. You are in for a treat. My mother’s fried chicken is why we had to buy my dad the extra large coffin.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, she just got off the plane. She doesn’t want to cook.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course she does. Making me food is her way of saying I love you. Making me food when she’s too tired to cook is her way of saying I really love you.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Actually, I wouldn’t mind going out for a bite, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Won’t that spoil our appetites for the chicken you’re going to make me?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: All right, that settles it, we’re going out. Do you like sushi? There’s a great little place down the street.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I’ve never had it, but there’s no harm in trying something new.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There’s a lot of harm in trying something new. That’s why we test out drugs and cosmetics on bunny rabbits.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, you’re talking like a crazy person.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Actually, I had him tested as a child. Doctor says he’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Told you.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Although, I do regret not following up with that specialist in Houston.

utterance.speaker: All
utterance.content: Irasshaimase!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Stop yelling! I’m not happy about this.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s the last thing you were ever happy about?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The prospect of fried chicken.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: This is exciting. Back home, the diner on Route Four serves sushi, but it’s just cut up fish sticks and a side of Uncle Ben’s. They put it on the menu in those kung fu letters, but that don’t make it sushi.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, kung fu letters might not be politically correct.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, I thought the one we couldn’t say was ching chong.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, that, too.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: So, Shelly, what’s up with you and your friend Amy, if you don’t mind a mother prying a bit?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, there’s actually big news on the Amy front. She’s been studying the neurobiology of addiction in lower animals. She is this close to getting a starfish hooked on cocaine.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Do you have any idea what’s going on with those two?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s kind of like the Loch Ness monster. Maybe there’s something there, maybe there isn’t. We’ll probably never know. But sometimes it’s fun to creep yourself out thinking about it.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: How are you doing on the young lady front? I hear you’re in some sort of a long distance situation?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, yeah, it’s Raj’s sister. It’s kind of tough. She’s in India. Also, her parents aren’t happy she’s dating someone white.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, that’s a funny turn, isn’t it? You never think about it going the other way. Well, you can’t force things. You need to figure out if you’re in a relationship or if you’re just calling it one. It’s like they say, a cat can have kittens in the oven but that don’t make ’em biscuits.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And that reminds me of another saying. You can lead a chicken to Crisco, but you can’tmake your mother fry it.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Sheldon, you pester me one more time about chicken, I will put you over my knee right here in this restaurant.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Please pester her. Please, for me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, Mrs. Cooper, what did you think of the sushi?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: It was good. The only thing that would have made it better is if it was cooked and if it was beef. Sheldon, when is your landlord going to fix the elevator?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t know. Lately we’ve been talking about converting it into a missile silo.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Your son seems to think we need to launch a pre-emptive strike on Burbank.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Get them before they get us.

utterance.speaker: Raj (Sitting against their front door, drinking a beer)
utterance.content: Hey, look who decided to show up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Raj, what are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I couldn’t find you guys so I bought six new friends. Three, sadly, are dead.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Mom, you remember Rajesh? Rajesh, my mother.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Of course. Mrs. Cooper. So nice to see you again.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, it’s so nice to see you, too. I thought it was our Indians that had the occasional alcohol problem.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We don’t say that, either. I’ll make you a list.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, that would be mighty white of you. So, Raj, what pain are you trying to cover up with alcohol?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Nothing, I’m fine.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Are ya?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: That’s better. Now tell me what’s bothering you.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m so lonely.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, yes, born alone, die alone. It’s a tragic human condition. Now, Raj, if you’ll excuse my mother, she’s about to make a pecan pie that’ll be so good I’ll almost forget how she blew it with the fried chicken.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Sheldon, your friend is hurtin’. What do we do when someone’s hurtin’?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Offer them a hot beverage.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: And when they’re drunk as a skunk, what beverage do we offer?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Coffee.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: And what do we do it with? Now you listen to me. I know you feel like you can’t find someone, but there’s a lock for every key. Back home, there’s a girl works at the Wal-Mart. Tall, tall girl. Woman could hunt geese with a rake. Thought she’d never find a man, then one day, wouldn’t ya know, Harlem Globetrotters come to town. Long story short, today that woman travels the world with a semi-professional basketball player and two beautiful mixed-race babies.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I didn’t get a lot of that because of your accent, but the general tone was soothing and somehow I feel better.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not going to get my pecan pie, am I?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You want some Oreos?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Double Stuf?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, regular.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nice. Kick a man when he’s down.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m glad we’re finally getting to do something together, just the two of us.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Sure. One thing you really miss when you’re on vacation is laundry.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Careful, you’re using too much Downey. You know if my clothes get too soft it makes me sleepy.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, this takes me back. Me doing your laundry, you next to me criticizing.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It is nice, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Penny (arriving)
utterance.content: Mrs. Cooper. Hi!

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, hello, darlin’.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, you didn’t tell me your mom was coming.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It was in my weekly e-mail blast. Right between beet season is finally here, and uh-oh, red stool from beets leads to cancer scare.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: So, how’ve you been?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Good, good.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I hear that Leonard has a new girlfriend. How are you doing with all that?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, fine. You know, it’s been a while. I’m getting back out there.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Let me ask you, when you get back out there, are you wearing this?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, it’s super cute on. That top has paid for itself in free drinks like ten times what it cost.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, Penny has a lot of her money tied up in promiscuity futures.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Hon, you think maybe the reason why you’re having trouble finding a guy to settle down with is because you’re letting them ride the roller coaster without buying a ticket?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, they don’t always get to ride the roller coaster. Sometimes they only get to spin the teacups. Now I’m going out tonight. Would it be crazy to ask you to look at the outfit I’m going to wear?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, not crazy at all. And don’t beat yourself up. When I was your age, you could have me for a car ride and a bottle of strawberry wine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now that will not be in this week’s e-mail blast.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, this spring, I get to go to the International Space Station.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, my word, a trip to the heavens. If you ever want to live there eternally, I’ve got a good book you could read.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thanks, but I watch the Charlie Brown Christmas special every year, so I get the gist.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I bet your mom is really proud of you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Nope. She says if I don’t back out she’s going to go on a hunger strike. It would take years before she’d be in any kind of danger, but still.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ve got a treat for us tomorrow, Mom. I’m taking you to see Saul Perlmutter give a lecture about his Nobel Prize-winning work in cosmology. And the best part is, at the Q and A afterward, I’ve worked up a couple of Q’s that will stump his sorry A.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I don’t know, Shelly. I thought we could do a little sightseeing.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What sight is better than your little boy embarrassing a Nobel laureate?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Come on, Sheldon, we’ll take your mom to see the Hollywood sign, the wax museum, the Walk of Fame.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ooh, maybe a little Rodeo Drive.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, I can’t spend twelve thousand dollars on a handbag, but it’s free to look upon those who do with righteous condemnation.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What do you say?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What do I say? I say you people need to stop ruining my mom’s visit with your sushi, and your sadness and your slutty shirts. Stop it.

utterance.speaker: Howard (after Raj whispers to him)
utterance.content: He’s not talking about your shirt. Your shirt is fine.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: These are delicious.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: The trick to pancakes is bacon grease. I cook everything in it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Everything? Aren’t you worried about your health?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, doctors are always changing their mind. One week bacon grease is bad for you. The next week we’re not getting enough of it. Good morning, Shelly.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Mom, I want to apologize for my behaviour last night.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Apology accepted.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Great. Now, you’re going to love the Perlmutter lecture. Look, he will be stating that the universe is older than 6,000 years, but I thought you could stick your fingers in your ears and hum Amazing Grace during those parts.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I am still going out with your friends.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But I apologized. And that was hard for me because I didn’t do anything wrong.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Shelly, I hung out with you in enough dusty lecture halls while you were growing up. I want to go sightseeing. So why don’t you have some pancakes, get dressed and come with us.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not going, and you can’t make me.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You’re right, I can’t. Have a nice day.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I’m going to stand here until you change your mind.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, then you are going to stand there all day.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m just gonna take my bacon grease and slide over there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can’t believe my own mother is abandoning me.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I am not abandoning you. Sheldon, abandoning you is leaving you in a basket on a church doorstep. I am going to Hollywood and thank a wax Ronald Reagan for his service to our country.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We appear to be at a crossroads in our relationship, Mother.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, I guess we are.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sorry. Syrup.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, Mom. When you’re at the Ripley’s Believe It Or Not Museum, if they have an exhibit about a mother who threw away a chance to spend the day with the world’s most wonderful son, believe it, because it’s true.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I hadn’t…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That lecture was a waste of time. I made more accurate diagrams of the expansion of the early universe on the nursery wall with the contents of my diaper.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Are you getting sick?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, I’m just allergic to people who get Nobel Prizes for no good reason.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, is it possible that your foul mood, or, to use the clinical term, bitchiness, is because your mother isn’t making you a priority?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. Or to use the clinical term, nuh-uh.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Are you sure? The infant-mother pair-bond is the building block of primate psychology.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, there it is. It always comes back to monkeys with you. Just monkeys, monkeys, monkeys.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, we’re all animals. And granted, there are aspects of you that are extraordinary, but when it comes to emotions and relationships, you’re just like everybody else.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you trying to suggest that my emotional problems are no different than those of a stupid person?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Actually, some research indicates that by not over-thinking, the less intelligent handle emotions better. Sure you’re not coming down with a cold?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, yes, the common cold. Just like everyone else. You’d love that, wouldn’t you?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, this one’s sweet. You know, for your rosary rattlers.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Mrs. Cooper, we say Catholics, not rosary rattlers.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: My goodness, it’s a wonder you people in California can talk at all.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: This is like the worst Hollywood tour ever.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What are you gonna do? She wanted to see churches.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, they have wine here, don’t they?

utterance.speaker: Raj (pointing at a crucifixion statue)
utterance.content: Hey, none of our gods have abs like that.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yep, that’s the last Jew who did sit-ups. And look where it got him.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Hey, while we’re here, why don’t we all do some praying? Let’s put a little church in this church.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, I’m not sure we should.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: It’s easy. I’ll show you how. Lord, Mary Cooper here. Coming to you from Gomorrah, California. I want to thank you for the blessing that is my little Shelly. I also want to thank you for the continued strength not to coldcock him with my Bible. All right, Penny, your turn.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, um, hey, God. What’s up? Um, I’m good, but, uh, it would be a big help to my family if you could get my brother to stop cooking meth. But no cops. Be cool.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: She also goes a little overboard on the love thy neighbour. Could probably use that chat you had with Mary Magdalene. Leonard, you’re up. Wasserman, you’re on deck.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay. I don’t know, it’s probably a little late to ask you to make me taller. Oh, um, if you could help out with me and my girlfriend. She’s all the way in India. That would be great.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Hear that? Girl trouble. Turns out we were both wrong on that front. How about you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, me? No. Thanks, I’m good. I’m really just trying not to burst into flames.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Rajesh?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: He says he’s having trouble dropping those last five pounds.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Huh, I might have gone with the talking-to-girls thing.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, you only get one wish.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Look at the two of us. Me, a highly regarded physicist. The kind of mind that comes along once, maybe twice in a generation. You, the common man, tired from your labours as a stockbroker, or vacuum cleaner salesman, or bootblack. But deep down inside, apparently we’re just two peas in a pod. A regular pea, and the kind of pea that comes along once, maybe twice in a generation. Rain. Another great equalizer. Falling on the head of the brilliant and the unremarkable alike. Smarty-pants.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, Mrs. Cooper, it smells so good.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You take notes, darlin’. The real way to get a man is with melted cheese and cream of mushroom soup. He’ll die at 50 but his love will be true.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (entering, soaked)
utterance.content: I need a tissue.This one got wet.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you. Yeah, I’ve learned something today. You and I, in so many ways, other than intelligence and what counts, we’re the same.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Sweetheart, are you sick?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I hope so, because if this is well, life isn’t worth living.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, sugarpie, you are burning up. We’ve got to get you to bed.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Don’t worry. Mama’s here to take care of her baby.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And just to be clear, only her baby and not these other people.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Can I have tea with honey and toast with the crust cut off?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You can have whatever you want.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thanks, Mom.You’re the best.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Boy, last time I put VapoRub on you, you didn’t have hair on your chest.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I know, it filled in last year. I didn’t get to spend a lot of time with you on this visit.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: And whose fault was that?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yours.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Shelly, you’re not eight years old any more. We have to have a different relationship.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, we don’t. The one we have works great.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Sweetheart, you are a grown man.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Or maybe I’m part of a new species, that lives for hundreds of years, which means I’m still basically a toddler.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, I so should have taken you to Houston.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Does this mean you’re not going to sing Soft Kitty?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: No, I will always sing you Soft Kitty. Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur…

utterance.speaker: Leonard (at door)
utterance.content: Mrs. Cooper, were we supposed to take that pie out of the oven?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Get out!

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, that was rude.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I know, but he means well. Sing.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Happy kitty, sleepy kitty…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What are you trying to pull, Mom? From the top.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper (to God)
utterance.content: This is what I’m talking about. Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur…
